Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient is at a routine check-up and has general questions about their health.
Story:
I glanced at my phone as I finished up with my last patient of the afternoon, a gentle elderly woman who had just asked about her cholesterol levels. I answered her questions with a calm, reassuring tone, making sure she understood her next steps. As I walked her out, my phone buzzed again—this time, a message from my stepbrother. He’d just gotten home from school and wrote, “Can you come talk? Had a rough day.” I could picture him slumped on the couch, eyes red, needing someone to listen. 

But in the waiting room, another patient was already filling out forms, expecting my full attention and expertise. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my stepbrother needed me as family, to be present and supportive, while my patient needed me as a doctor, to be attentive and professional. My heart tugged in two directions, guilt and responsibility swirling together as I stood frozen between the exam room and the door, unsure which role to step into first.
